qas.question: When did the FAA change it's long-standing approach to air traffic control candidates?
What was now favored instead of training and experince at flight schools?
Who could be an air traffic controller irrespective of experience now because of the rule change?
What did applicants now take that many of them found baffling?
What kind of degree do you need to be considered?
When did the agency switch to a system where people could be "fast-tracked" for consideration?
How did applicants find the biological questionnaire?
Who switched to an open system for candidates who completed the coursework at participating colleges?

context: In <a0_0><b5_0>2014<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the FAA changed a long-standing approach to air traffic control candidates that eliminated preferences based on training and experience at flight schools in favor of a <a1_0>personality test<a1_0/> open to <a2_0>anyone<a2_0/> irrespective of experience. The move was made to increase flight traffic controller racial diversity. Before the change, candidates who had completed coursework at participating colleges and universities could be "fast-tracked" for consideration. The <b7_0>agency<b7_0/> eliminated that program and instead switched to an open system to the general public, with no need for any experience or even a <b4_0>college<b4_0/> degree. Instead, applicants could take "a <a3_0>biographical questionnaire<a3_0/>" that many applicants found <b6_0>baffling<b6_0/>.
